titleStmt.title: Sex-specific effects of advanced maternal age on cardiovascular function in aged adult rat offspring

analytic.title: Sex-specific effects of advanced maternal age on cardiovascular function in aged adult rat offspring

biblStruct.note: Submitted 18 June 2018; accepted in final form 1 October 2018

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Pregnancy at an advanced maternal age has an increased risk of complications for both the mothers and their offspring.
We have previously shown that advanced maternal age in a rat model leads to poor fetal outcomes, maternal vascular dysfunction, and hypertension, concordant with findings in humans.
Moreover, offspring from aged dams had sexspecific cardiovascular dysfunction in young adulthood.
However, the detrimental impact of aging on the cardiovascular system of the offspring in this model is unknown.
We hypothesized that offspring born to aged dams (9.5-10 mo old) would have impaired cardiovascular function at 12 mo of age.

Echocardiographic data revealed signs of mild left ventricular diastolic dysfunction in only male offspring from aged dams [isovolumetric relaxation time: 34.27 Ϯ 2.04 in the young dam group vs. 27.61
Ϯ 0.99 ms in the aged dam group, P Ͻ 0.01; mitral annular velocity ratio (E=/A=): 1.08 Ϯ 0.04 in the young dam group vs. 0.96 Ϯ 0.02 in the aged dam group, P Ͻ 0.05].
We have previously shown that in young adulthood (4 mo of age), male, but not female, offspring born to aged dams had impaired recovery from ischemia-reperfusion injury.
Aging did not alter the susceptibility of female offspring to ischemia-reperfusion injury.

Interestingly, wire myography data revealed that male offspring from aged dams had enhanced vascular sensitivity to methacholine (negative log of EC 50: 7.4 Ϯ 0.08 in young dams vs. 7.9 Ϯ 0.11 in aged dams, P ϭ 0.007) due, in part, to increased prostaglandin-mediated vasodilation.
Despite intact endothelium-dependent relaxation, female offspring from aged dams had elevated systolic blood pressure (125.3
Ϯ 4.2 mmHg in young dams vs. 144.0
Ϯ 6.9 mmHg in aged dams, P ϭ 0.03).
These data highlight sex-specific mechanisms underlying cardiovascular programming in offspring born to dams of advanced age.

NEW & NOTEWORTHY Our study demonstrated that adult male and female offspring (12 mo old) born to aged dams had impaired cardiac diastolic function and increased blood pressure, respectively, signifying sex-specific differential cardiovascular effects of advanced maternal age.
Advanced maternal age, defined as childbearing by women of Ն35 yr of age, is on the rise worldwide, particularly in developed countries (5, 29, 37a, 55a).
In the United States and Canada, births occurring among advanced maternal age women constitute 14% and 18% of total live births, respectively (29, 50a).
Several epidemiological studies have shown that advanced maternal age is associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes affecting both mothers and babies.

For instance, advanced maternal age is associated with increased risk of developing preeclampsia (22,37), intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) (26,36), preterm birth (20,23), and stillbirth (26,39).
Therefore, given that the trend of childbearing at an advanced age is increasing (37b), these complications pose a significant clinical concern to both maternal and fetal health.
It is now well recognized that a suboptimal intrauterine environment can modulate an individual's later-life cardiovascular health (for reviews, see Refs. 2, 8, and 31).
Several animal and human studies have shown adverse cardiovascular outcomes in adults who experienced a compromised in utero environment (for a review, see Refs. 2 and 17).

In animal models, cardiovascular dysfunction has been shown in offspring born from complicated pregnancies induced by a variety of maternal manipulations such as nutrient restriction (10), protein restriction (55), and uterine artery ligation (1).
We and others have demonstrated that adult offspring exposed to prenatal hypoxia had less cardiac tolerance to ischemia-reperfusion (I/R) insult (28,42).

However, in vivo cardiac function and flow-induced vasodilation were intact in young offspring exposed to prenatal hypoxia (32,42) but were impaired after exposure to secondary insults such as in vivo myocardial ischemia (49) or aging (32,43).
In fact, age is an important risk factor for cardiovascular disease in the general population (35) and is associated with increased levels of markers of oxidative stress and inflammation (51).
Aging therefore might act as a secondary stress factor in a susceptible population exposed to prenatal insults.

In a baboon model, using calorie restriction as prenatal insult, Kuo et al. (24) observed a cardiac phenotype in young adults (abnormal cardiac remodeling and impaired cardiac function) that was similar to normally aged control animals, suggesting accelerated cardiac aging in adult offspring born to calorierestricted mothers.

Furthermore, using a reduced uteroplacental perfusion pressure-induced IUGR rat model, Dasinger et al. (14) have shown increased blood pressure in 12-mo-old male offspring compared with age-matched control animals.
Thus, there is evidence that the effect of developmental programming may worsen as offspring age.
More interestingly, and pertinent to the present study, evidence exists that advanced maternal age is associated with adverse health outcomes in offspring in later life.
Children born to advanced maternal age mothers are at a higher risk of developing diabetes (25), impaired cognitive ability, and autism spectrum disorders (27).

Recently, a few animal studies have shown impaired glucose metabolism (54), high blood pressure (54), increased anxiety-like behaviors, and altered patterns of hippocampal gene expression (45) in adult offspring born to advanced maternal age mice.

Using a novel rat model of advanced maternal age, we have recently shown poor pregnancy outcomes such as reduced litter size, IUGR, and altered maternal vascular function (11), indicating the presence of a suboptimal intrauterine environment.
Overall, these findings support the theory that advanced maternal age is a risk factor for developmental programming of health and disease.

Furthermore, our previous study (12) demonstrated impaired recovery of cardiac function after ischemia, and endothelial dysfunction was demonstrated in 4-mo-old male, but not female, offspring born to dams of advanced age.
These data illustrate a sex-specific developmental programming effect of maternal age on offspring cardiovascular risk.
However, the cardiovascular susceptibility of adult offspring born to aged dams in later life (12 mo of age) is not known.
Furthermore, the sexual dichotomy of cardiovascular phenotype in aged offspring remains to be determined.
Thus, we hypothesized that aged adult offspring born to advanced maternal age dams would have increased susceptibility to cardiovascular dysfunction in a sex-dependent manner.
Animal model.
Female Sprague-Dawley rats were purchased from Charles River (St.
Constant, QC, Canada) at 3 mo of age and housed in a temperature-controlled room (22 Ϯ 1°C) with a 10:14-h lightdark cycle.
After acclimatization for 1 wk, rats were randomly allocated to a young dam (3-4 mo old, n ϭ 13) or aged dam (9.5-10 mo old, n ϭ 10) group for mating with young male rats (aged 3-5 mo).

As previously described, young rats were fed chow ad libitum, whereas rats in the advanced maternal age group were maintained on a controlled-feeding regime until pregnancy to limit the development of obesity (11).
In the controlled-feeding group, six pellets of chow a day per rat was provided, based on National Research Council recommendations for caloric and nutrient intake (33).

At the time of conception, rats in the aged pregnancy group were 9.5-10 mo of age, which is ~35 yr of age in humans considering milestones such as weaning, skeletal maturity, and reproductive senescence (48).
Pregnancy was confirmed by the presence of sperm in vaginal smears, which was designated gestational day 0 (GD0).
After birth, litters were reduced to eight pups (4 male pups and 4 female pups) whenever possible.
In the advanced maternal age group, we did not always get a litter size of eight or more, in which case there was no intervention.
In particular, some of the aged dam litters had fewer male offspring, and two of the 12-mo-old male offspring from aged dams died before ex vivo experimentation, leading to n ϭ 4 for these protocols.
When the litter had fewer than four male pups, additional female pups were left until weaning to maintain a similar nursing environment among the litters.
At 3 wk of age, pups were weaned, housed in same-sex pairs, and fed on chow diet ad libitum.
At 12 mo of age, offspring were used for experimentation.
Offspring were randomized to experimental protocols such that for each of the study parameters no two animals came from the same litter.

div.head: Animal ethics.

p.s: Blood pressure measurement.
At 12 mo of age, blood pressure was measured by tail-cuff plethysmography (CODA, Kent Scientific, Torrington, CT) in male and female offspring.
Rats were subjected to a 1-wk training period for acclimatization.
After rats were placed in restraint tubes for 20 min to warm and acclimate to the environment (tail skin surface temperature ~30°C), blood pressure was recorded.
An average was taken of at least 10 blood pressure measurements performed over a period of 10 min.
Blood pressure measurements were taken ~1 wk before cardiac and vascular function experiments.
Echocardiography.
Echocardiography was performed at 12 mo of age in male and female offspring.
Left ventricular (LV) morphology and function were assessed in male and female offspring by noninvasive transthoracic echocardiography as previously described (38).
All echocardiographic assessments were performed by a single operator who was blinded to the experimental groups.

With a highresolution in vivo microimaging system (Vevo 2100, Visualsonics, Toronto, ON, Canada) equipped with a 13-to 23-MHz linear array transducer, echocardiography was performed in either a supine or a semi-left lateral decubitus position.

Animals were anesthetized (sedated with 4% isoflurane and maintained at 1-1.5% isoflurane, 1 l/min compressed air), the chest and abdomen were shaved, and the limbs were fixed to the electrodes on the table surface with tape and electrode gel.
The electrocardiogram and respiratory rate were continuously recorded.
Echocardiography was performed in two-dimensional guided M mode, and the heart was imaged in the parasternal short-axis view with a depth of 2 cm.
From this view, an M-mode cursor was positioned perpendicular to the anterior and posterior wall of the LV at the level of the papillary muscles.

LV internal diameters during diastole (LVID d) and systole (LVIDs), diastolic and systolic LV septal wall thickness (IVSd and IVSs), and diastolic and systolic LV posterior wall thickness (LVPWd and LVPWs) were obtained.

Ejection fraction (EF) and fractional shortening (FS) were calculated with ventricular diameters and volumes obtained from M-mode images according to American Society of Echocardiography recommendations (44) as follows:

div.formula: EF ͑%͒ ϭ ͓͑LVEDV Ϫ LVESV͒ ⁄ LVEDV͔ ϫ 100 FS ͑%͒ ϭ ͓͑LVIDd Ϫ LVID s͒ ⁄ LVESV͔ ϫ 100

p.s: where LVEDV is LV end-diastolic volume and LVESV is LV end-systolic volume.
LV mass was also automatically calculated with M-mode images by the uncorrected cube function formula as follows:

div.formula: LV mass(g) ϭ 1.053 ϫ ͓͑LVID d ϩ LVPW d ϩ IVS d͒ 3 Ϫ LVID d 3 ͔

p.s: where 1.053 is the specific gravity of the myocardium.
In the apical four-chamber view, the transmitral flow velocity profile (early rapid filling E wave velocity and late filling atrial contraction A wave velocity) was obtained.
E and A wave images were used to quantify isovolumic relaxation time (IVRT) and isovolumic contraction time, E-to-A ratio, and deceleration time of the E wave.
Tissue Doppler imaging was used to obtain mitral annular velocities (E= and A=).
Pulmonary artery Doppler imaging was used to measure pulmonary acceleration time (PAT) and pulmonary ejection time (PET).
Isolated working heart preparation.
Isolated working hearts were prepared with previously described methods (50).

Female rats were anesthetized with a dose of 1.5 ml of isoflurane inhalation, and the heart was rapidly excised and kept in ice-cold modified Krebs-Henseleit solution [containing (in mM) 120 NaCl, 25 NaHCO3, 5.5 glucose, 4.7 KCl, 1.2 KH 2PO4, 1.2 MgSO4, and 2.5 CaCl2 (pH 7.4)].
After cannulation and ligation of the aorta, hearts were perfused with oxygenated Krebs-Henseleit solution for 10 min in the retrograde Langendorff mode.
During this period, excess pericardial tissues were removed and the left atrium was cannulated and ligated with silk and switched to anterograde working mode.
After stabilization, hearts were perfused for 30 min (preischemia period) followed by 10 min of global ischemia and 40 min (postischemia period) of reperfusion.
Cardiac function was reported as cardiac power, calculated as follows: [peak systolic pressure (mmHg) Ϫ maximal preload (mmHg)] ϫ cardiac output (ml/min) ϫ 0.13/dry weight (J•min•g Ϫ1 dry wt Ϫ1 ).
Cardiac parameters were recorded with a Hugo Sachs Electronik data-acquisition system and ISOHEART software for Windows 2000 (Harvard Apparatus).
Cardiac power was calculated every 10 min for a period of 80 min.
Data obtained from nonreversible arrhythmic hearts during the experiment were excluded from the study.
Wire myography.

Rats were anesthetized with isoflurane (dosed to effect by inhalation) and euthanized by exsanguination via either cardiac puncture or rapid excision of the heart for isolated working heart experiments.
Vascular function was assessed in mesenteric resistance arteries from 12-mo-old male and female offspring from young and aged dams.

Second-order mesenteric arteries (150 -250 m) were rapidly excised, cleaned, and dissected in ice-cold HEPESbuffered physiological saline solution [containing (in mM) 142 NaCl, 4.7 KCl, 1.17 MgSO4, 4.7 CaCl2, 1.18 K2PO4, 10 HEPES, and 5.5 glucose (pH 7.4)].
Arteries were mounted on an isometric myograph system (DMT, Copenhagen, Denmark) with 40-m tungsten wire.

Arteries were normalized through a series of stepwise increases in diameter to determine 0.8L100 (where L100 is the estimated vessel internal circumference in situ under a transmural pressure of 100 mmHg).

After a 30-min equilibration period, vessels were treated twice with phenylephrine (PE; 10 M, Sigma) and once with methacholine (MCh; 3 M, Sigma) to assess functionality of the vascular smooth muscle and endothelium, respectively.
After a washout period, cumulative concentration-response curves were assessed to two vasoconstrictors in separate vessels: PE (0.01-100 M) and U46619 (thromboxane mimetic, 0.001-30 M, Sigma).

After a second washout period, arteries were incubated for 30 min with inhibitors added to the bathing physiological saline solution medium before preconstriction with an EC80 concentration of PE and stimulation with cumulative doses of MCh (0.003-3 M, Sigma).

The influence of the following inhibitors on MCh-induced vasorelaxation was tested: N G -nitro-L-arginine methyl ester (L-NAME; 100 M, Sigma), a pan-inhibitor of nitric oxide synthase (NOS); indomethacin (Indo; 5 M, Sigma), a nonselective inhibitor of prostaglandin H synthase (PGHS); a combination of the K ϩ channel blockers apamin (100 nM, Sigma), a small-conductance Ca 2ϩ -activated K ϩ channel blocker, and 1-[(2-chlorophenyl)diphenylmethyl]-1H-pyrazole (TRAM-34; 10 M, Sigma), an intermediate-conductance Ca 2ϩactivated K ϩ channel blocker; polyethylene glycol-superoxide dismutase (PEG-SOD; 50 U/ml, Sigma), a superoxide scavenger; or SQ29548 (10 M, Sigma), a thromboxane A2 receptor antagonist.

At the completion of each experiment, the bathing medium was changed to 124 mM KCl solution [high-KCl buffer; containing (in mM) 10 HEPES, 24 NaCl, 124 KCl, 2.4 MgSO 4, 4.9 CaCl2, 1.18 KH 2PO4, and 5.5 glucose (pH 7.4)] to assess maximal nonreceptormediated constriction.
Immunofluorescence.

LV sections (9 m thick) were fixed with cold acetone for 10 min and incubated overnight at 4°C in a humid chamber with collagen type I (COL1A1) antibody (1:1,000, Novus Biologicals) or rabbit polyclonal collagen type III (COL3A1) antibody (1:2,000, Abcam).

Sections were incubated with secondary antibody Alexa Fluor 488 donkey anti-rabbit (1:200, ThermoFisher Scientific) or Alexa Fluor 546 goat anti-rabbit (1:200, ThermoFisher Scientific), respectively, for 1 h at room temperature in a humid chamber.
All slides were mounted with DAPI-containing mounting medium to stain for cell nuclei and coverslipped.
Three or four random, nonoverlapping image fields were captured with a ϫ20 objective lens (ϫ200 magnification), and average results are reported.

An Olympus IX81 microscope (Olympus Canada, Toronto, ON, Canada) with a CoolSNAP HQ2 charge-coupled device camera (Photometrics) operated by CellSens Dimensions 1.9 software (Olympus Canada) was used for visualization and image capture.
Images were analyzed with ImageJ software (NIH, Bethesda, MD).
Western blot analysis.

LV or mesenteric artery tissue (50 -100 mg) homogenates were prepared in lysis buffer [containing (in mM) 20 Tris (pH 7.4), 5 EDTA, 10 sodium pyrophosphate tetrabasic, 100 sodium, and 9 fluoride with 1% Nonidet P-40] containing protease [protease inhibitor cocktail (1ϫ Halt protease inhibitor, Thermo Scientific)], 1 mM PMSF (Fluka Biochemika), and phosphatase inhibitor (2 mM sodium orthovanadate, Sigma).
Total protein concentration of the lysate was determined by a bicinchoninic acid assay (Pierce, Rockford, IL).

Total protein was loaded and separated on 10% SDS-polyacrylamide gels for prostacyclin synthase (PGIS), 7.5% SDS-polyacrylamide gels for sarco(endo)plasmic reticulum Ca 2ϩ -ATPase 2a (SERCA2a), and 4 -15% gradient gels (Mini-PROTEAN TGX precast gels, Bio-Rad, Mississauga, ON, Canada) for ryanodine receptor 2 (RYR2).
Proteins were then transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane (0.2 m, Bio-Rad), which was incubated with 50% blocking reagent for 1 h at room temperature.

After a wash with PBS, the membrane was incubated overnight at 4°C with primary antibodies for SERCA2a (LV tissues, 1:2,500, Santa Cruz Biotechnology), RYR2 (LV tissues, 1:1,000, Abcam), PGIS (mesenteric arteries, 1:1,500 rabbit polyclonal, AVIVA Systems Biology), or ␤-actin (1:1,000 -1,500, Santa Cruz Biotechnology).

Membranes were then incubated with the appropriate secondary antibody: IRDye 800CW donkey anti-mouse and IRDye 680RD goat anti-rabbit IgG, IRDye 800CW donkey anti-rabbit IgG and IRDye 680RD donkey anti-mouse IgG (1:10,000 -1:20,000, LI-COR Biosciences, Lincoln, NE), or antimouse (Alexa Fluor 750, 1:20,000, Invitrogen).
Blots were then visualized with a LI-COR Odyssey Bioimager and quantified by densitometry with Odyssey V3.0 software (LI-COR Biosciences).
All data are expressed as percent increases/decreases over the corresponding control (tissue from young dams for each sex).
Statistical analyses.
Male and female offspring were analyzed separately because of their profound differences in phenotype (e.g., body size).
Results are presented as means Ϯ SE and were analyzed with GraphPad Prism software (version 6.0).
Offspring characteristics (body weight and blood pressure), cardiac function recovery after I/R, and echocardiographic and molecular data were analyzed with Student's t-tests.
To analyze vascular function data, concentration-response curves were fitted to the Hill equation, from which a sigmoid plot was generated by nonlinear least-squares regression analysis.

The negative log of the mean effective concentration that produced either 30% or 50% of the maximal response (pEC30 or pEC50) or the difference between percent maximal relaxation (⌬Emax) for each treatment was then determined.
Comparisons of summary Emax, pEC30, pEC50, and ⌬Emax data were made with a Student's t-test or two-way ANOVA with a Bonferroni's post hoc test for multiple
Offspring weight and blood pressure.

A previous study (11) from our laboratory using this model demonstrated that pups born to advanced maternal age dams were smaller at gestational day 21 than those from young dams, despite smaller litter sizes and unaffected blood flow through the umbilical and uterine arteries.
In the present study, at 12 mo of age, there was no significant difference in body weight of offspring born to either young or aged dams (Table 1).
Blood pressure was not different in male offspring from young dams compared with aged dams (Table 1).
However, systolic blood pressure was increased in 12-mo-old female offspring from aged dams compared with control animals (P Ͻ 0.05; Table 1).
In vivo LV morphometry and function in aged adult offspring.
Echocardiographic data showed that there were no significant differences in LV size or wall morphometry between the groups in either male or female offspring (Table 2).

Likewise, cardiac systolic function was similar between groups in both male and female offspring born to young or aged dams, as evidenced by LV functional parameters such as stroke volume, cardiac output, EF, and FS (Table 3).
Parameters of diastolic function, such as the E-to-A ratio, E-to-E= ratio, and deceleration time, were unaltered in female offspring from young or aged dams (Table 4).

However, in male offspring, the IVRT and E=-to-A= ratio, markers of diastolic dysfunction, were significantly decreased in male off-spring born to aged dams compared with offspring born to young dams, indicating echocardiographic signs of mild LV diastolic dysfunction (Fig. 1).
Left atrial diameter, a physiological marker of the duration and severity of diastolic dysfunction (41), was similar between groups in both male and female offspring (Table 4).
Pulmonary artery function in aged adult offspring.

Pulmonary arterial hypertension, a clinical manifestation often associated with LV diastolic dysfunction, was assessed via pulmonary artery Doppler parameters PAT and PET and reported as the PAT-to-PET ratio.

The PAT-to-PET ratio was similar between groups in both male and female offspring [male offspring: 0.40 Ϯ 0.03 in the young dam group vs. 0.42 Ϯ 0.02 in the aged dam group, not significant (NS): female offspring: 0.42 Ϯ 0.03 in the young dam group vs. 0.44 Ϯ 0.02 in the aged dam group, NS], indicating no echocardiographic signs of pulmonary hypertension.

In addition, postmortem data revealed similar lung-to-body weight ratios between the groups in male and female offspring (male offspring: 2.68 Ϯ 0.10 mg/g in the young dam group vs. 2.52 Ϯ 0.08 mg/g in the aged dam group, NS: female offspring: 3.65 Ϯ 0.05 mg/g in the young dam group vs. 3.31 Ϯ 0.17 mg/g in the aged dam group, NS).
Ex vivo cardiac function in aged adult female offspring.

After the observation of intact in vivo cardiac function in female offspring born to aged dams, we assessed whether this cardioprotective effect would persist when offspring were exposed to an additional insult such as ex vivo I/R injury.
For this reason, and the fact that male offspring were already affected at 4 mo of age, we performed ex vivo I/R experiments in 12-mo-old female offspring only.
Baseline cardiac function during preischemia was similar between the groups (Fig. 2, B).

Contrary to our expectation, recovery of cardiac function after I/R was not significantly different in female offspring born to aged dams compared with offspring born to young dams, indicating a persisting level of cardioprotection against I/R injury even with aging (Fig. 2, A and C).
Molecular analyses of cardiac collagen type I and III, SERCA2a, and RYR2 protein levels in aged adult offspring.

Because we observed signs of mild in vivo cardiac diastolic dysfunction in male offspring born to aged dams, we assessed tissue levels of collagen types I and III and Ca 2ϩ -handling proteins such as SERCA2a and RYR2, which have been associated with diastolic dysfunction (40), in LV tissue from male offspring.
Immunofluorescence and Western blot data revealed that there were no differences in the cardiac collagen type I-to-III ratio, SERCA2a, and RYR2 between the groups (Fig. 3 and Fig. 4).
Vascular function in aged adult offspring.

In male offspring, endothelium-dependent relaxation responses were not impaired with maternal age; indeed, vascular sensitivity to MCh was increased in mesenteric arteries from 12-mo-old offspring of aged dams (Fig. 5A).
In female offspring, endotheliumdependent relaxation remained similar in offspring born to young versus aged dams (Fig. 5B).

Interestingly, nonspecific inhibition of PGHS with Indo impaired vasorelaxation only in male offspring from aged dams (male MCh pEC 30 control vs. Indo: 7.75 Ϯ 0.1 vs. 7.89 Ϯ 0.19 in the young dam group, NS; 8.25 Ϯ 0.16 vs. 7.67 Ϯ 0.08 in the aged dam group, P Ͻ 0.05), suggesting an increased contribution of a PGHS-dependent vasodilator in the aged dam group.
Preincubation with Indo had no significant effect on vasorelaxation in female offspring from either maternal age group (data not shown).

Blockade of PGHS-dependent constriction with the thromboxane receptor antagonist SQ29548 did not affect sensitivity to MCh in either male or female offspring, although there appeared to be an effect of dam age in both groups (Table 5).

Inhibition of endothelium-dependent hyperpolarization with apamin-TRAM-34 and NOS inhibition with L-NAME impaired MCh-induced relaxation in all groups of offspring, but there was no significant effect of dam age on the impact of these inhibitors on vascular responses to MCh (Table 5).
PEG-SOD preincubation did not affect relaxation of vessels from either male or female 12-mo-old offspring (Table 5).
Vascular sensitivity to the thromboxane mimetic U46619 was reduced in female offspring from aged dams (U46619 pEC 50 for female offspring: 7.06 Ϯ 0.10 in the young dam group vs. 6.59
Ϯ 0.07 in the aged dam group, P Ͻ 0.05), as were constriction responses to PE (PE pEC 50 for female offspring: 5.8 Ϯ 0.05 in the young dam group vs. 5.5 Ϯ 0.01 in the aged dam group, P Ͻ 0.05).
There were no differences in vasoconstriction to U46619 or PE in male offspring at 12 mo of age (data not shown).
Molecular analysis of vascular PGIS in aged adult offspring.

Because of the unexpected finding of enhanced vasodilation in male offspring from aged dams that appeared to be mediated by a PGHS-derived vasodilator, we quantified the expression of PGIS in mesenteric arteries.
Indeed, by Western blot analysis, PGIS protein levels were found to be significantly elevated only in male offspring born to aged dams (Fig. 6).
Advanced maternal age is known to be associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes (20,22).

However, its effect on Overall, our results demonstrated that the effect of advanced maternal age on offspring later-life cardiovascular health is complex and sex specific with differential cardiovascular impact, with male offspring being more susceptible to the development of cardiac dysfunction, whereas female offspring may be more susceptible to the development of hypertension.

Evidence from epidemiological and experimental studies have established a clear link between prenatal factors and susceptibility to later-life cardiovascular diseases (for reviews, see Refs. 2 and 8).

Moreover, adult cardiovascular outcomes in a susceptible population (exposed to a prenatal insult) seem to be sex specific (13), which has also been demonstrated in a variety of animal models including the maternal low-protein rat (30), sheep (52), and hypoxic rat (57).

Recently, we demonstrated the presence of a compromised intrauterine environment in a rat model of advanced maternal age, as indicated by poor pregnancy outcomes and maternal vascular dysfunction (11).
Furthermore, at 4 mo of age male, but not female, offspring born to advanced maternal age dams had impaired cardiac function recovery to I/R injury and endothelial dysfunction (12).

In light of this previous observation, and knowing the impact of aging on the cardiovascular system (47), we examined whether advanced maternal age would affect in vivo cardiovascular outcomes and whether female offspring would show susceptibility to cardiac I/R injury at an older age (12 mo old).

We found that only male offspring born to advanced maternal age dams developed mild in vivo diastolic dysfunction, as indicated by a decreased IVRT and E=-to-A= ratio compared with offspring born to young dams, demonstrating a persistence of the sex-specific phenotype of developmental programming on cardiovascular dysfunction.

Furthermore, and contrary to our expectation, female offspring born to advanced maternal age dams continued to demonstrate cardiac tolerance to an additional insult (ex vivo I/R injury) at 12 mo of age, signifying ongoing cardioprotection in female offspring from aged dams.

In contrast, a previous study (42) by our group using a rat model of prenatal hypoxia showed that both male and female offspring had signs of cardiovascular dysfunction at 12 mo of age and not during young adulthood.
In fact, it is indicated that insults in fetal life may affect responses of different tissues, including the heart, to the normal aging process (for a review, see Ref.
Fig. 4. Representative Western blot images for cardiac sarco(endo)plasmic reticulum Ca 2ϩ -ATPase 2a (SERCA2a) and ryanodine receptor 2 (RYR2) protein levels.
Cardiac SERCA2a (A) and RYR2 (B) protein levels in aged (12 mo old) adult male offspring were unaltered between the groups.
Blots were quantified with Odyssey software.
Data were collected as triplicates from each sample and were normalized to ␤-actin.
All groups were compared with a Student's t-test (n ϭ 5 or 6).
nutrient-restricted dams.
Our laboratory has observed echocardiographic signs of pulmonary hypertension in aged adult (12 mo old) male and female prenatal hypoxia-induced IUGR offspring (42).
In contrast, we did not observe signs of pulmonary hypertension in 12-mo-old offspring of either sex born to advanced maternal age dams.

This demonstrates that in male rat offspring the effect of aging on offspring born to advanced maternal age dams caused a more subtle LV diastolic dysfunction without leading to the manifestation of a pulmonary vascular pathology, suggesting a unique pathophysiological programming phenotype in offspring from advanced maternal age dams.
Multiple pathophysiological changes such as extracellular matrix composition and intracellular Ca 2ϩ -handling machinery have been noted to play a role in cardiac diastolic dysfunction (40).

In neonatal and young adult offspring born to both hypoxic (53,56) and nutrient-restricted (18) dams, there is evidence of altered cardiac extracellular matrix composition and impaired Ca 2ϩ handling, which might be an underlying mechanism contributing to cardiac diastolic dysfunction.
Increases in LV fibrosis, stiffness, and wall thickness are age dependent and promote cardiac diastolic dysfunction (21).
In our rat model of advanced maternal age, we did not observe any conventional signs of fibrosis in the heart as indicated by unaltered cardiac collagen type I-to-type III ratio between the groups.
Furthermore, molecular markers of diastolic dysfunction such as SERCA2a or RYR2 protein levels were similar between the groups in male offspring.
Thus, aged offspring born to dams of advanced maternal age present with mild in vivo diastolic dysfunction; however, the mechanistic pathways remain to be elucidated.

Regarding the effect of maternal age on offspring mesenteric artery function, contrary to our hypothesis, sensitivity to endothelium-dependent relaxation was increased in 12-mo-old male offspring from aged dams.
Conversely, in female offspring, vascular relaxation was similar between offspring born to young and aged dams.

Interestingly, the enhanced sensitivity to vasodilators in male offspring from aged dams may be a compensatory mechanism, given that only female offspring from aged dams demonstrated elevated systolic blood pressure.

However, we recognize that the sensitivity of noninvasive blood pressure measurements is limited and because of a smaller number of animals in the male offspring group, mild changes in blood pressure may be missed (in male offspring) or exaggerated (in female offspring).
Nevertheless, these apparent discordant results have been seen in other models of developmental programming such as in the low-protein rat model of IUGR.
Indeed, in aged (100 wk old) female IUGR offspring, 5. Endothelium-dependent relaxation was enhanced in aged (12 mo old) male but not female offspring born to aged dams.

Sensitivity to methacholine (MCh) was significantly increased in mesenteric arteries from male offspring from aged dams, as indicated by an elevated negative log of mean effective concentration producing 50% of maximal response (pEC50; inset) (A), whereas relaxation was not altered in female offspring from aged versus young dams (B).
n ϭ 4 -8 animals/group.
*P Ͻ 0.05 by Student's t-test.
mean arterial pressure was increased without evidence of renal impairment or vascular endothelial cell dysfunction.
These results, along with our own, illustrate the complex pathophysiology behind programmed hypertension.

Increased vascular relaxation in aged male offspring may be secondary to increased prostaglandin-mediated vasodilation, given the significant effect of Indo on sensitivity to MCh as well as the increased expression of PGIS only in aged male offspring from advanced maternal age dams.
To the best of our knowledge, this compensatory increase in PGIS has not been observed in other animal models of systemic vascular dysfunction.

However, PGIS expression has been shown to be upregulated in a rat model of hypoxia-induced pulmonary hypertension, in which the primary stimulator of increased PGIS is thought to be shear stress (9).
Furthermore, an important role of PGIS in essential hypertension is well known; humans possessing genetic polymorphisms of the PGIS gene are at high risk for the development of hypertension (19).

Although the function of aging on the vasculature is known to be impacted by prooxidant pathways, there was no significant effect of PEG-SOD on modulating vascular relaxation in either male or female offspring at 12 mo of age.

Despite evidence that both NOS-and endothelium-dependent hyperpolarization-dependent pathways were also involved in mediating endotheliumdependent relaxation in aged male and female offspring, there was no significant effect of dam age on these vascular pathways.

Overall, endothelium-dependent relaxation was not affected in aged female offspring from aged dams, yet vasoconstriction to both PE and a thromboxane mimetic was reduced, as was overall sensitivity to the thromboxane receptor blocker SQ29548.

These data may indicate that aged female offspring from advanced maternal age dams demonstrate an exaggerated vascular aging phenomenon, characterized by a decreased sensitivity to vasoconstrictors (15).
However, systolic blood pressure was specifically elevated only in this group, suggest-ing that the blood pressure regulatory capacity (a physiologically complex mechanism) is affected.
Thus, decreased sensitivity to PE and U46619 could also be an attempt at compensating for an overall constrictive phenotype, manifesting as hypertension in this offspring group.
Regardless, given that this unique pathophysiological response was observed only in females born to aged dams, further studies are necessary to elucidate the underlying mechanism for these findings.
In conclusion, advanced maternal age increases the risk of later-life cardiovascular disease in aged offspring via sexspecific mechanisms and a differential impact on the vascular system.
Male offspring appear more susceptible to development of cardiac dysfunction, whereas female offspring may be prone to develop hypertension.

Given the increasing trend toward delayed parenthood, these findings have significant population and health care implications; the role of maternal age on long-term offspring health warrants further investigation.
